titles.title: Sǝnkǝssar “Synaxarion” (the second half of the year)

shortcontents.shortcontent:
I) Sǝnkǝssar ”Synaxarion” for the second half of the year (fols. 3ra-162vc): I-1) Mäggabit (fols. 3ra-28rc) I-2) Miyazya (fols. 28va-48vc) I-3) Gǝnbot (fols. 48va-76vc) - Zä-ʾaqräbku maḫletä… “The song I am offering…” (concluding prayer): fol. 76rb I-4) Säne (fols. 77ra-101vc) I-5) Ḥamle (fols. 102ra-132rc) I-6) Näḥase (fols. 132ra-158ra) I-7) Ṗagwǝmen (fols. 158ra-162vc) The commemorative notices are followed by ʿarke-hymns
Additiones 1-2.

originlink.xlink:title: ʿAddigrat Däbrä Mänkәrat Qәddus Qirqos / AMQ

locationlink.xlink:title: ʿAddigrat Däbrä Mänkәrat Qәddus Qirqos / AMQ

copyists.copyist: Wäldä Maryam is mentioned as the scribe in a subscription on fol 76vc. Possibly he is the same scribe as that of Ms. SMM-001.

donors.donor: šum ʾagame Kasa (Wäldä ʾArägawi) is mentioned as the donor in Additio 1, with his father Wäldä Kidan (ras Sǝbḥat ʾArägawi) and his mother Wälättä Yoḥannǝs. The names are also mentioned in the supplication formulas, Wäldä ʾArägawi throughout the Ms., Wäldä Kidan (e.g., fols. 102vc, 139rc, 140vc), and Wälättä Yoḥannǝs (e.g., fols. 76vb, 132rc).

dcomments.dcomment: According to Additio 1 the Ms. was donated in 1918/19. Additio 1 also mentions ʾAskalä Maryam, the baptismal name of Queen Zäwditu (r. 1916-30).

txstates.txstate: Holes and tears are carefully amended on fols. 12, 28, 65, 70, 72, 87. A small portion of the text has been washed out on fol. 122vc.

bindings.binding: Two wooden boards covered with reddish-brown tooled leather; textile inlays. Two pairs of sewing stations.

bndecorations.bndecoration: Blind tooled ornament visible on the the reddish-brown leather cover(at least 6 tools were used: triple line fillet, double circle, 2 types of cross hatching, double sine wave with dots, quatrefoil).

bnothers.bnother: Two pairs of chains of endband stitches at the spine cover.

squires.squire: A(2; s.l.: 1, stub after 1; 2, stub after 1/fols. 1r-2v) – [፩]I(8/fols. 3r-10v) – [፪]II(8/fols. 11r-18v) – ፫III(8/fols. 19r-26v) – [፬]IV(8/fols. 27r-34v) – ፭V(8/fols. 35r-42v) – ፮VI(8/fols. 43r-50v) – ፯VII(8; s.l.: 3, stub after 6; 7, stub after 1/fols. 51r-58v) – ፰VIII(8/fols. 59r-66v) – IX(10; s.l.: 3, stub after 7; 8, stub after 2/fols. 77r-76v) – X(8/fols. 77r-84v) – XI(8/fols. 85r-92v) – XII(8/fols. 93r-100v) – XIII(8/fols. 101r-108v) – XIV(8; s.l.: 3, stub after 6; 6, stub after 3/fols. 109r-116v) – XV(8/fols. 117r-124v) – XVI(8/fols. 125r-132v) – XVII(8/fols. 133r-140v) – XVIII(8/fols. 141r-148v) – XIX(8/fols. 149r-156v) – XX(8/fols. 157r-164v).

taunit.rl-info: Ruling and pricking are visible. Ruling pattern: 1E-1E-1E1E/0-0/0-0/C. Primary pricks are visible. Ruling pricks are visible. The upper line is written above the ruling. The bottom line is written above the ruling.

pchangeofhands.pchangeofhand: The handwriting is characterized by small letters tending to broad shapes (e.g., ራ and ል), thick strokes and pronounced shadings. - the vowel marker of ግ is set on a long stroke - some left pointing elements of letters have forked shapes, e.g., ት and ብ.

rubrications.rubrication: Nomina sacra; the word sälam; the name of the donor (and his family members); several lines or groups of lines on the page opening the commemorative notices for each month; one or two initial lines of each commemorative notice; elements of the punctuation signs (e.g., nine dot asterisks in red and black, separating the commemoration notes); elements of Ethiopic numerals.

otherdetails.otherdetail: - On fol. 76vb, at the end of the month Gǝnbot, the scribe wrote the concluding prayer Zä-ʾaqräbku maḫletä… “The song I am offering…”, followed by a supplication of the scribe himself and the donor: Fol. 76vc: ማኅበረ፡ ነቢያት፡ ወሐዋርያት፡ ማኅበረ፡ ጻድቃን፡ ወሰማዕት። ማኅበረ፡ ደናግል፡… ዘአንበብክሙ፡ ወዘተርጉምክሙ፡ ዘወሀብክሙ፡ መብዓ፡ ለቤተ፡ ክርስቲያን፡ በጸሎተ፡ ኵሎሙ፡ ቅዱሳን፡ ወሰማዕት፡ ለጸሐፊሁ፡ ኃጥእ፡ ወምስኪን፡ ወልደ፡ ማርያማ። ወለዘአጽሐፊሁ፡ ወልደ፡ አረጋዊ።።። ለዓለመ፡ ዓለም፡ አሜን፡ ወአሜን፡ ለይኩን፡ ለይኩን ። The scribe’s name is Wäldä Maryam. Written by the same hand as the main text, except for the name "Wäldä ʾArägawi". - The scribe wrote directives for the ministers as to when to read the concluding prayer Zä-ʾaqräbku maḫletä… “The prayer I have offered…” on fol. 162vb. That is on 6. Ṗagwǝmen it should be read one time and on 5. Ṗagwǝmen two times.

additional.cont: Fol. 162vc: Donation note.
additional.det: The note indicates that šum ʾagame Kasa (baptismal name Wäldä ʾArägawi) donated the book to the church ʿAddigrat Däbrä Mänkәrat Qәddus Qirqos. The name of his father was ras Sǝbḥat ʾArägawi (baptismal name Wäldä Kidan), and the name of his mother was Wälättä Yoḥannǝs. The year given is 1911 year of mercy (1918/19 A.D.), during the reign of Queen ʾAskalä Maryam (the baptismal name of Queen Zäwditu, r. 1916-30). Kasa is known also from the Mss. MKL-005, MKL-006, GBI-001, BGY-006. The names appear to have been inserted in a secondary hand, probably that of the donors' names elsewhere in the Ms.

additional.cont: Fol. 163r: The concluding prayer Zä-ˀaqräbku maḫletä… “The prayer I have offered…”
additional.det: It is written in blue pen by a recent hand in the bottom margin of the fol.

extras.extra: - The title ስክሳር [sic] is crudely written on fol. 1r. - In order to complete the end of a word the written line is taken up, e.g., fols. 7vb l.3, 59rb l.12, 149va l.18. - Words or passages of the text are repeated in a very small script in the margins of many fols. On fol. 9r in modern red pen; all the other notes are by the same hand (?) as the main text: fols. 2v, 4r, 45v, 46v, 47r, 58r, 81r, 90r, etc. - Parts of the concluding prayer Zä-ʾaqräbku maḫletä… are scribbled in red modern ink on fol. 162vbc. It is the continuation of the prayer which was started by the scribe in column b but left incomplete.

drawing.details: Fol. 163r: Ink drawing of the Virgin Mary in the style of the Hodegetria, with the Child seated on her left arm, framed by two angels holding a canopy in the background. The Virgin is pointing her right hand to the heavens instead of to the Child, who is pointing both hands in an upward direction as well. The lines are drawn with a sure, if not entirely professional hand, with carefully etched dress detailing in flowing lines.
